frameDefinitions: This frame contains general locale words, and is mostly a place-holder in the hierarchy.
This frame concerns a Perceiver's state of readiness to process and consider impressions of a Figure within a Ground.
An Event with multiple Participants takes place.
These adjectives describe the degree of strictness or tolerance of an Agent, usually with regard to another person (the Controllee) and often with regard to a particular Issue.
An Emitter emits a Beam of light from a Source, along a Path, and/or towards a Goal.
A perceptible Figure shows up against a Ground location due to Light shining on/from it, its salience possibly dependent on a Cause_of_shine.
frameExamples: Legislator tells consumers to be <t>alert</t> to dioxin levels.
MATAC looks forward to your <t>participation</t> in helping promote telework in the Mid-Atlantic region.
Court says judge too <t>lenient</t> in rape case.INI
Avoid allowing light to <t>shine</t> into neighbors' gardens.
listRoleDefinitions: A stable bounded area.  It is typically the designation of the nouns of Locale-derived frames.
The individual that pays attention to the <fen>Ground</fen>.
The entity that the <fen>Perceiver</fen> is specifically focussing on within the <fen>Ground</fen>.
An entity (or event) associated with a <fen>Perceiver</fen> that gives evidence for a <fen>Perceiver</fen>'s attentiveness.
The individuals or entities that have been participants in an <fen>Event</fen>.
<fen>Participant_1</fen> is the grammatically more prominent participant in an <fen>Event</fen> with multiple <fen>Participants</fen>.
A grammatically less prominent participant of an <fen>Event</fen> with multiple <fen>Participants</fen>.
An <fen>Event</fen> with multiple <fen>Participants</fen>, who may or may not be involved intentionally.
A group, location, or institution conventionally associated with an <fen>Event</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the multiple-participant <fen>Event</fen> occurs.
The location where the <fen>Event</fen> involving multiple <fen>Participants</fen> occurs.

The Agent is the person who is strict or liberal in his/her control over another. This role is usually the External Argument with predicate adjectives, or the head noun if the adjective is used attributively: <fex name='Agent'>The school</fex> is very <t>liberal</t> in approach and curriculum. I attended a very <t>liberal</t> <fex name='Agent'>school</fex>.

The Agent's strictness may be directed towards or limited to some particular person or group over whom he/she has control.  The Controlled_entity generally occurs in a PP Complement.
Grandparents are often <t>indulgent</t> <fex name='Controlled_entity'>with their grandchildren</fex>.
The Agent's strictness may be manifested in particular behavior: The judge was <t>lenient</t> <fex name='Controlling_act'>in dealing with the offender</fex>.

The Agent may be strict or lenient with respect to a particular matter or situation.  Issue occurs in PP Complements, usually headed by <ment>about</ment>: The city council is <t>strict</t> <fex name='Issue'>about pollution control</fex>.

A Medium of control, such as rules, may also be described as strict or lenient.  Medium may occur with or without the Agent who ultimately has control (i.e. the one who implements or enforces the rules). The club has <t>strict</t> <fex name='Medium'>rules</fex> about who can become a member. <fex name='Medium'>Immigration law</fex> is very <t>strict</t>.
The body part or expression of the <fen>Agent</fen> that indicates their strictness.
This role identifies the entity at the <fen>Source</fen> from which the <fen>Beam</fen> originates.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the location the <fen>Beam</fen> occupies initially before its change of location.
The light that travels from a <fen>Source</fen> along a <fen>Path</fen> to a <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Path</fen> refers to where the <fen>Beam</fen> travels over or to a landmark the <fen>Beam</fen> travels by.
<fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Beam</fen> ends up in.
The percept which is perceived at a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location.
The location of the phenomenon.
The <fen>Light</fen> which is emitted.  In this frame, it is usually incorporated in verbs and adjectives, and is the denotation of many of the nouns.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Figure</fen> is observed against the <fen>Ground</fen> location due to <fen>Light</fen> shining on it.
The spatial setting in which the <fen>Figure</fen> shows up against a <fen>Ground</fen> location.
listRoleExamples: There used to be a forest in that area.
Thereafter, <fex>everybody</fex> participated in the 17 May parade ending in the Nordic Club.
Last year, <fex>Bill</fex> participated in the Montana State University Earth Systems Science distance learning course in the Atmosphere Unit.

The Second Amended Complaint alleges that Andrew S. Pitt ('Pitt'), Conectisys Corporation ('Conectisys' or the 'Company'), and BM
Capital Corp. participated <fex>with Zaman and Smith Benton</fex> in a fraudulent and manipulative trading scheme.
Some who participated <fex>in D-Day</fex> are finally ready to talk about it
Several of the countries were unable to participate <fex>in the market</fex> .

A survey of students who participated <fex>last year</fex> showed that 61 percent would be the
first in their family to attend college.
The most exciting tours for Mr. Osako were when he participated <fex>in France, Belgium, Holland, Cuba and Japan</fex>.
I like to think he quaked under my authoritarian <fex>glare</fex>.
<fex>Sunlight</fex> gleamed from the water of the bay.
Hot coals glowed <fex>behind the fire grate</fex>.
<fex>In the morning</fex> the grass glistened with dew
<fex>Outside</fex> something was shimmering on the shore.
